AI.motivation: The motivation is to address the limitations of existing rate-distortion bounds in TOSC, which rely on strong assumptions and ignore the suboptimality of deployed task models in realistic scenarios.
AI.method: The authors analyze TOSC through indirect rate-distortion theory, propose new model-aware rate-distortion bounds that consider task model limitations, and conduct experiments to evaluate existing TOSC schemes.
AI.result: They find that current TOSC schemes perform significantly below the theoretical bounds, primarily due to the computational limitations on the transmitter side.
AI.conclusion: The study identifies a need for more efficient TOSC schemes that account for practical constraints, such as task model suboptimality, to optimize task performance under resource limitations.

title: Contextual Online Bilateral Trade
summary:
We study repeated bilateral trade when the valuations of the sellers and the buyers are contextual. More precisely, the agents' valuations are given by the inner product of a context vector with two unknown $d$-dimensional vectors -- one for the buyers and one for the sellers.
  At each time step $t$, the learner receives a context and posts two prices, one for the seller and one for the buyer, and the trade happens if both agents accept their price. We study two objectives for this problem, gain from trade and profit, proving no-regret with respect to a surprisingly strong benchmark: the best omniscient dynamic strategy.
  In the natural scenario where the learner observes \emph{separately} whether the agents accept their price -- the so-called \emph{two-bit} feedback -- we design algorithms that achieve $O(d\log d)$ regret for gain from trade, and $O(d \log\log T + d\log d)$ regret for profit maximization. Both results are tight, up to the $\log(d)$ factor, and implement per-step budget balance, meaning that the learner never incurs negative profit.
  In the less informative \emph{one-bit} feedback model, the learner only observes whether a trade happens or not. For this scenario, we show that the tight two-bit regret regimes are still attainable, at the cost of allowing the learner to possibly incur a small negative profit of order $O(d\log d)$, which is notably independent of the time horizon. As a final set of results, we investigate the combination of one-bit feedback and per-step budget balance. There, we design an algorithm for gain from trade that suffers regret independent of the time horizon, but \emph{exponential} in the dimension $d$. For profit maximization, we maintain this exponential dependence on the dimension, which gets multiplied by a $\log T$ factor.

AI.tldr: This paper studies repeated bilateral trade with contextual valuations where contexts determine buyer and seller valuations. It focuses on two objectives—gain from trade and profit—introducing no-regret algorithms with respect to strong benchmarks. Results exhibit tight regret bounds achieved under different feedback models (two-bit vs. one-bit), addressing settings with budget balance constraints.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to address the challenge of designing no-regret algorithms for repeated bilateral trade in scenarios where buyer and seller valuations are context-dependent. Moreover, it seeks to establish robust performance guarantees against strong benchmarks under practical feedback scenarios.
AI.method: The paper designs algorithms with tight regret bounds for gain from trade and profit under two feedback models: 1) two-bit feedback (observing acceptance separately), and 2) one-bit feedback (observing only whether trade occurred). It achieves no-regret results while considering budget balance and explores the tradeoff between feedback informativeness and algorithm performance.
AI.result: The methods achieve tight regret bounds of $O(d\log d)$ for gain from trade and $O(d\log\log T + d\log d)$ for profit maximization in two-bit feedback. Similar regret rates are attainable under one-bit feedback, albeit with potentially small negative profit. Tight regret bounds hold when enforcing budget balance, though at the expense of exponential dependence on dimension $d$.
AI.conclusion: The study significantly advances understanding of regret in repeated bilateral trade by proposing algorithms with tight bounds under different feedback levels. It highlights trade-offs between feedback levels, profit constraints, and algorithm performance with strong guarantees, enabling practical applications in trade systems.

title: Nonparametric Contextual Online Bilateral Trade
summary: We study the problem of contextual online bilateral trade. At each round, the learner faces a seller-buyer pair and must propose a trade price without observing their private valuations for the item being sold. The goal of the learner is to post prices to facilitate trades between the two parties. Before posting a price, the learner observes a $d$-dimensional context vector that influences the agent's valuations. Prior work in the contextual setting has focused on linear models. In this work, we tackle a general nonparametric setting in which the buyer's and seller's valuations behave according to arbitrary Lipschitz functions of the context. We design an algorithm that leverages contextual information through a hierarchical tree construction and guarantees regret $\widetilde{O}(T^{{(d-1)}/d})$. Remarkably, our algorithm operates under two stringent features of the setting: (1) one-bit feedback, where the learner only observes whether a trade occurred or not, and (2) strong budget balance, where the learner cannot subsidize or profit from the market participants. We further provide a matching lower bound in the full-feedback setting, demonstrating the tightness of our regret bound.

AI.tldr: The paper addresses the problem of contextual online bilateral trade with nonparametric valuation models using Lipschitz functions, proposing a new algorithm with strong regret guarantees.
AI.motivation: To improve trade facilitation in a contextual seller-buyer market with minimal feedback and strong budget constraints.
AI.method: Developed a hierarchical tree-based algorithm leveraging contextual information for general Lipschitz function-based valuations, achieving regret bounded by $\widetilde{O}(T^{(d-1)/d})$.
AI.result: Achieved a regret bound of $\widetilde{O}(T^{(d-1)/d})$ and established a matching lower bound in the full-feedback setting.
AI.conclusion: The proposed algorithm efficiently handles one-bit feedback and strong budget balance, providing tight regret bounds in the nonparametric trade setting.

title: Jointly Optimizing Debiased CTR and Uplift for Coupons Marketing: A Unified Causal Framework
summary:
In online advertising, marketing interventions such as coupons introduce significant confounding bias into Click-Through Rate (CTR) prediction. Observed clicks reflect a mixture of users' intrinsic preferences and the uplift induced by these interventions. This causes conventional models to miscalibrate base CTRs, which distorts downstream ranking and billing decisions. Furthermore, marketing interventions often operate as multi-valued treatments with varying magnitudes, introducing additional complexity to CTR prediction.
  To address these issues, we propose the \textbf{Uni}fied \textbf{M}ulti-\textbf{V}alued \textbf{T}reatment Network (UniMVT). Specifically, UniMVT disentangles confounding factors from treatment-sensitive representations, enabling a full-space counterfactual inference module to jointly reconstruct the debiased base CTR and intensity-response curves. To handle the complexity of multi-valued treatments, UniMVT employs an auxiliary intensity estimation task to capture treatment propensities and devise a unit uplift objective that normalizes the intervention effect. This ensures comparable estimation across the continuous coupon-value spectrum. UniMVT simultaneously achieves debiased CTR prediction for accurate system calibration and precise uplift estimation for incentive allocation. Extensive experiments on synthetic and industrial datasets demonstrate UniMVT's superiority in both predictive accuracy and calibration. Furthermore, real-world A/B tests confirm that UniMVT significantly improves business metrics through more effective coupon distribution.

AI.tldr: This paper addresses confounding bias in CTR prediction introduced by marketing interventions. It proposes the UniMVT framework to disentangle factors and enable debiased predictions and efficient coupon allocation.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to solve the problem of confounding bias in CTR prediction caused by marketing interventions like coupons, which miscalibrate base CTRs and impact downstream processes.
AI.method: The paper introduces UniMVT, a model that separates confounding factors, incorporates full-space counterfactual inference, uses intensity estimation for multi-valued treatments, and normalizes the intervention effect.
AI.result: Experiments on synthetic and industrial datasets show UniMVT's improved prediction accuracy and calibration. Real-world A/B tests demonstrate better business metrics with efficient coupon distribution.
AI.conclusion: UniMVT successfully addresses confounding bias in CTR prediction, enabling more accurate system calibration and effective incentive allocation, benefiting business outcomes.

title: Barron-Wiener-Laguerre models
summary: We propose a probabilistic extension of Wiener-Laguerre models for causal operator learning. Classical Wiener-Laguerre models parameterize stable linear dynamics using orthonormal Laguerre bases and apply a static nonlinear map to the resulting features. While structurally efficient and interpretable, they provide only deterministic point estimates. We reinterpret the nonlinear component through the lens of Barron function approximation, viewing two-layer networks, random Fourier features, and extreme learning machines as discretizations of integral representations over parameter measures. This perspective naturally admits Bayesian inference on the nonlinear map and yields posterior predictive uncertainty. By combining Laguerre-parameterized causal dynamics with probabilistic Barron-type nonlinear approximators, we obtain a structured yet expressive class of causal operators equipped with uncertainty quantification. The resulting framework bridges classical system identification and modern measure-based function approximation, providing a principled approach to time-series modeling and nonlinear systems identification.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a probabilistic extension to Wiener-Laguerre models for causal systems, incorporating Bayesian inference to provide uncertainty quantification.
AI.motivation: Classical Wiener-Laguerre models enable structured and interpretable system identification but lack uncertainty quantification.
AI.method: Bayesian inference is applied to Barron-type nonlinear approximators within the Laguerre model framework, merging classical linear modeling with probabilistic nonlinear approximation.
AI.result: The extended models generate causal operators that offer both expressive modeling capabilities and posterior predictive uncertainty.
AI.conclusion: This approach combines classical system identification with modern Bayesian methods for improved time-series modeling and nonlinear system identification.

title: Improved Regret Guarantees for Online Mirror Descent using a Portfolio of Mirror Maps
summary:
OMD and its variants give a flexible framework for OCO where the performance depends crucially on the choice of the mirror map. While the geometries underlying OPGD and OEG, both special cases of OMD, are well understood, it remains a challenging open question on how to construct an optimal mirror map for any given constrained set and a general family of loss functions, e.g., sparse losses. Motivated by parameterizing a near-optimal set of mirror maps, we consider a simpler question: is it even possible to obtain polynomial gains in regret by using mirror maps for geometries that interpolate between $L_1$ and $L_2$, which may not be possible by restricting to only OEG ($L_1$) or OPGD ($L_2$).
  Our main result answers this question positively. We show that mirror maps based on block norms adapt better to the sparsity of loss functions, compared to previous $L_p$ (for $p \in [1, 2]$) interpolations. In particular, we construct a family of online convex optimization instances in $\mathbb{R}^d$, where block norm-based mirror maps achieve a provable polynomial (in $d$) improvement in regret over OEG and OPGD for sparse loss functions. We then turn to the setting in which the sparsity level of the loss functions is unknown. In this case, the choice of geometry itself becomes an online decision problem. We first show that naively switching between OEG and OPGD can incur linear regret, highlighting the intrinsic difficulty of geometry selection. To overcome this issue, we propose a meta-algorithm based on multiplicative weights that dynamically selects among a family of uniform block norms. We show that this approach effectively tunes OMD to the sparsity of the losses, yielding adaptive regret guarantees. Overall, our results demonstrate that online mirror-map selection can significantly enhance the ability of OMD to exploit sparsity in online convex optimization.

AI.tldr: This paper explores improving the Online Mirror Descent (OMD) method in Online Convex Optimization (OCO) for sparse loss functions by introducing mirror maps based on block norms and develops a meta-algorithm for adaptive geometry selection.
AI.motivation: To address the open question on constructing an optimal mirror map for constrained sets under sparse loss functions and achieve better adaptability in OMD.
AI.method: Introduces block norm-based mirror maps that interpolate between $L_1$ and $L_2$ geometries and proposes a meta-algorithm using multiplicative weights for adaptive geometry selection in an online setting.
AI.result: Proves polynomial regret gains using block norm mirror maps over existing $L_1$ (OEG) and $L_2$ (OPGD) geometries for sparse losses. Demonstrates adaptivity with the proposed meta-algorithm to unknown sparsity levels.
AI.conclusion: The study establishes that proper mirror-map selection can dramatically improve regret by leveraging sparsity, and adaptive approaches address the challenge of unknown sparsity levels in OMD.

title: Selection of CMIP6 Models for Regional Precipitation Projection and Climate Change Assessment in the Jhelum and Chenab River Basins
summary: Effective water resource management depends on accurate projections of flows in water channels. For projected climate data, use of different General Circulation Models (GCM) simulates contrasting results. This study shows selection of GCM for the latest generation CMIP6 for hydroclimate change impact studies. Envelope based method was used for the selection, which includes components based on machine learning techniques, allowing the selection of GCMs without the need for in-situ reference data. According to our knowledge, for the first time, such a comparison was performed for the CMIP6 Shared Socioeconomic Pathway (SSP) scenarios data. In addition, the effect of climate change under SSP scenarios was studied, along with the calculation of extreme indices. Finally, GCMs were compared to quantify spatiotemporal differences between CMIP5 and CMIP6 data. Results provide NorESM2 LM, FGOALS g3 as selected models for the Jhelum and Chenab River. Highly vulnerable regions under the effect of climate change were highlighted through spatial maps, which included parts of Punjab, Jammu, and Kashmir. Upon comparison of CMIP5 and CMIP6, no discernible difference was found between the RCP and SSP scenarios precipitation projections. In the future, more detailed statistical comparisons could further reinforce the proposition.

AI.tldr: The paper discusses GCM selection for CMIP6 hydroclimate studies and compares it to CMIP5. Results highlight highly vulnerable areas and show no major differences between CMIP5 and CMIP6 precipitation projections.
AI.motivation: This study aims to identify appropriate General Circulation Models (GCMs) for CMIP6 to simulate hydroclimate impacts and evaluate differences with CMIP5 projections, aiding better water resource management.
AI.method: The study used an envelope-based method, incorporating machine learning components, for GCM selection without requiring in-situ data. It also compared CMIP5 and CMIP6 using extreme indices and spatial mapping.
AI.result: Models NorESM2 LM and FGOALS g3 were identified for the Jhelum and Chenab River basins. Vulnerable regions, like Punjab, Jammu, and Kashmir, were highlighted without major precipitation projection differences between CMIP5/6.
AI.conclusion: The selection method effectively identifies GCMs for hydroclimate impact analysis under CMIP6. Vulnerable regions under climate change were mapped, and SSP scenarios showed similar precipitation projections to CMIP5.
